(1979). Gukanshō, p. 273; Varley, H. Paul. Jinnō Shōtōki, p. 143. Tenpyō-kanpō lasted only four months during the last year of Shōmu's reign. The previous era ended and this new one started in 749.Brown, p. 274. ==Events of the Tenpyō-kanpō era== * 749 (Tenpyō-kanpō 1, 2nd day of the 7th month): In the 25th year of Shōmu's reign, the emperor abdicated; and the succession (senso) was received by his daughter. Soon after, Empress Kōken's role as monarch was confirmed by ceremonies (sokui).Brown, p. 274; Varley, p. 44; a distinct act of senso is unrecognized prior to Emperor Tenji; and all sovereigns except Jitō, Yōzei, Go-Toba, and Fushimi have senso and sokui in the same year until the reign of Emperor Go-Murakami. Compare Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), Ceremony of Accession (Sokui-no-Rei); retrieved 2012-5-22. * 749 (Tenpyō-kanpō 1, 2nd day of the 7th month): To mark the beginning of Empress Kōken's regin, the Tenpyō- kanpō era ended and the new Tenpyō-Shōhō era started. ==Related pages== * Nara period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Tenpyō-kanpō 1st 749 Preceded by: Tenpyō Era or nengō: Tenpyō-kanpō Succeeded by: Tenpyō-shōhō Category:Japanese eras Category:749 Category:8th-century establishments in Japan Category:8th-century disestablishments in Japan Category:740s disestablishments Category:740s establishments Category:8th century in Japan
